class="detail-link-label sclt-storySectionLink"><a class="" href="/news/canada/british-columbia"><span>British Columbia</span></a></span><h1 class="detailHeadline" lang="en">5 SFU football players sue university over axed varsity program</h1><div class="detailSummary">Five SFU football players have filed an injunction in the Supreme Court of British Columbia to halt the university's heavily-criticized decision to cancel its varsity football program last week.</div><div class="share"><div class="viafoura"><h2 class="a11y">Social Sharing</h2><div class="vf-widget vf-share-bar-horizontal" data-widget="sharebar" data-button-view="false" data-url="https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/british-columbia/sfu-football-players-injunction-filed-1.6809900" data-show-labels="true" data-show-counters="false" data-show-total="false"></div></div></div><h2 class="deck" lang="en">Players and alumni hope injunction pressures university to reverse decision before trial</h2><div class="byline"><figure class="imageMedia author-image full" data-testid="image-figure"><div class="placeholder"><img loading="lazy" alt="" src="https://i.cbc.ca/1.6801137.1680629939!/fileImage/httpImage/image.jpeg_gen/derivatives/square_140/moira-wyton-headshot-08-2021.jpeg" data-testid="image-img"/></div></figure><div class="bylineDetails"><span class="authorText"><a class="" href="/author/moira-wyton-1.6801119">Moira Wyton</a></span> <span class="bullet"> · </span>CBC News<!-- --> <span class="bullet"> · </span><time class="timeStamp" dateTime="2023-04-14T04:32:11.865Z" data-testid="time">Posted: Apr 13, 2023 9:13 PM EDT | Last Updated: 6 hours ago</time></div></div><div class="storyWrapper"><figure class="imageMedia leadmedia-story full" data-testid="image-figure"><div class="placeholder"><img alt="Alumni and supporters of the Simon Fraser Football program are pictured outside of the courthouse in Vancouver, British Columbia on Thursday, April 13, 2023. " src="https://i.cbc.ca/1.6810218.1681431049!/cumulusImage/httpImage/image.jpg_gen/derivatives/16x9_780/sfu-football.jpg" data-testid="image-img"/></div><figcaption class="image-caption">Alumni and supporters of the Simon Fraser Football program are pictured outside of the courthouse in Vancouver on Thursday.<!-- --> <!-- -->(Ben Nelms/CBC)</figcaption></figure><div class="commentCount"><button class="commentCount-link"><div class="commentCount-text-container"><div class="viafoura"><vf-conversations-count></vf-conversations-count></div><div class="commentCount-text"><span> comments</span></div></div></button><span class="commentCount-icon"><svg viewBox="0 0 32 32" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true"><path d="M20.95,17H11a1,1,0,0,0,0,2h10a1,1,0,0,0,0-2Zm2-6H9a1,1,0,0,0,0,2h14a1,1,0,0,0,0-2ZM16,0C7.14,0,0,6.26,0,14a12.55,12.55,0,0,0,6,10.9v7.07l7-4.25a18.71,18.71,0,0,0,3,.25c8.82,0,16-6.25,16-14S24.78,0,16,0Zm0,25.95a16.29,16.29,0,0,1-3.37-.37l-4.7,2.82.06-4.63A11.56,11.56,0,0,1,2,14C2,7.36,8.24,2,16,2s14,5.36,14,12-6.26,12-14,12Zm0,0"></path></svg></span></div><div class="story"><p>Five SFU Football players have filed an injunction in the Supreme Court of British Columbia to halt the university's heavily-criticized decision to cancel its varsity football program last week.</p><p>In a separate civil claim, the players allege the decision by Simon Fraser University breached their contract despite its offer to honour their academic scholarships for one more year.</p><p>"These players all came to SFU based on promises … that they would play football and get a great education," said lawyer Peter Gall outside the Supreme Court of B.C. on Thursday afternoon. </p><p>"So with very little notice the program is now being terminated. We say that's a breach of contract."</p><div><ul class="similarLinks"><li class="similarListItem"><a href="https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/british-columbia/sfu-football-alumni-seeking-injunction-to-reinstate-axed-varsity-team-1.6806611" class="similarLink" text="SFU football alumni seeking injunction to reinstate axed varsity team" flag="" data-contentid=""><span class="similarLinkText">SFU football alumni seeking injunction to reinstate axed varsity team</span></a></li></ul><ul class="similarLinks"><li class="similarListItem"><a href="https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/british-columbia/b-c-football-community-in-shock-after-sfu-discontinues-its-varsity-program-1.6803293" class="similarLink" text="B.C. football community in shock after SFU discontinues its varsity program" flag="" data-contentid=""><span class="similarLinkText">B.C. football community in shock after SFU discontinues its varsity program</span></a></li></ul></div><p>None of the claims of either action have been tested or proven in court, and the university has not filed a formal response.</p><p>In a statement to CBC, a spokesperson said the university is aware of the injunction and will be "reviewing and considering next steps."</p><p>Last week, Simon Fraser University president Joy Johnson said the decision is a result of "ongoing uncertainty" due to the NCAA Division II Lone Star Conference announcing it would drop SFU Football beginning in 2024.</p><p>SFU Football is the only Canadian university team in the American NCAA II Division, and according to the claim has sent more players to the Canadian Football League than any other university. The school still had a place to play in the upcoming 2023 season.</p><div><em><strong>WATCH | Lawyer says terminating football program a 'breach of contract': </strong></em><span><span class="mediaEmbed" data-testid="parentSpan"><div class="player-placeholder-ui-container "><div class="player-placeholder-video-ui" title="Lawyer for axed SFU Football players calls injunction a last resort" role="button" tabindex="0"><div class="player-placeholder"></div><div class="player-placeholder-ui "><div class="video-item video-card-overlay " title="Lawyer for axed SFU Football players calls injunction a last resort"><div class="thumbnail-wrapper"><div class="thumbnail-container"><img srcSet="

fill="#000000"></path></svg></div><div class="video-info-container"><h3 class="video-item-title">Lawyer for axed SFU Football players calls injunction a last resort</h3><div class="video-time-container"><span class="formattedDate video-time-stamp">12 hours ago</span><div class="videoTimeLabel "><div class="durationLabel"><span><span class="a11y">Duration </span>1:03</span></div></div></div></div></div></div></div></div></div><span class="media-caption">Peter Gall hopes SFU will reinstate the team before May 3 "safety valve" deadline.</span></span></span></div><p>Players and SFU Football Alumni Association president Mark Bailey also say SFU did not take any steps to consult players, alumni, or explore other league options in Canada before deciding to end the program on April 4. </p><p>Since the school's decision, there's been much support for SFU Football. CFL commissioner Randy Ambrosie, Canadian Football League Players' Association executive director Brian Ramsay, and Football Canada president Jim Mullin have all written letters to Simon Fraser, U Sports and Canada West officials and football coaches condemning the decision and asking that SFU be allowed to continue playing football in Canada.</p><h2>Last resort</h2><p>Bailey and Gall hope the injunction pressures the university to reverse the decision before May 3 when the dispute goes to court.</p><p>"It's more about us moving forward and having ongoing conversation to get to where we need to be," said Bailey. "If we didn't file this, I don't know if we can get there."</p><p>SFU has offered players to continue their academic scholarships for one more year, but Gall and players say anything less than reinstating the program isn't enough.</p><p>"No other remedy will adequately compensate the (players) for what they will lose if the 2023 season is cancelled," the claim states.</p><p>Gall noted the decision's timing makes it impossible for many players to find a new team to play on before the next season begins, or for scheduling to take place if the SFU team is reinstated. </p><div><em><strong>WATCH | 'I don't think I can stay here' if football program not reinstated: SFU athlete </strong></em><span><span class="mediaEmbed" data-testid="parentSpan"><div class="player-placeholder-ui-container "><div class="player-placeholder-video-ui" title="SFU Football player says cancellation of program is 'devastating'" role="button" tabindex="0"><div class="player-placeholder"></div><div class="player-placeholder-ui "><div class="video-item video-card-overlay " title="SFU Football player says cancellation of program is 'devastating'"><div class="thumbnail-wrapper"><div class="thumbnail-container"><img srcSet="

description: Five SFU football players have filed an injunction in the Supreme Court of British Columbia to halt the university's heavily-criticized decision to cancel its varsity football program last week.
text: Five SFU Football players have filed an injunction in the Supreme Court of British Columbia to halt the university's heavily-criticized decision to cancel its varsity football program last week.In a separate civil claim, the players allege the decision by Simon Fraser University breached their contract despite its offer to honour their academic scholarships for one more year."These players all came to SFU based on promises … that they would play football and get a great education," said lawyer Peter Gall outside the Supreme Court of B.C. on Thursday afternoon. "So with very little notice the program is now being terminated. We say that's a breach of contract."None of the claims of either action have been tested or proven in court, and the university has not filed a formal response.In a statement to CBC, a spokesperson said the university is aware of the injunction and will be "reviewing and considering next steps."Last week, Simon Fraser University president Joy Johnson said the decision is a result of "ongoing uncertainty" due to the NCAA Division II Lone Star Conference announcing it would drop SFU Football beginning in 2024.SFU Football is the only Canadian university team in the American NCAA II Division, and according to the claim has sent more players to the Canadian Football League than any other university. The school still had a place to play in the upcoming 2023 season.Players and SFU Football Alumni Association president Mark Bailey also say SFU did not take any steps to consult players, alumni, or explore other league options in Canada before deciding to end the program on April 4. Since the school's decision, there's been much support for SFU Football. CFL commissioner Randy Ambrosie, Canadian Football League Players' Association executive director Brian Ramsay, and Football Canada president Jim Mullin have all written letters to Simon Fraser, U Sports and Canada West officials and football coaches condemning the decision and asking that SFU be allowed to continue playing football in Canada.Bailey and Gall hope the injunction pressures the university to reverse the decision before May 3 when the dispute goes to court."It's more about us moving forward and having ongoing conversation to get to where we need to be," said Bailey. "If we didn't file this, I don't know if we can get there."SFU has offered players to continue their academic scholarships for one more year, but Gall and players say anything less than reinstating the program isn't enough."No other remedy will adequately compensate the (players) for what they will lose if the 2023 season is cancelled," the claim states.Gall noted the decision's timing makes it impossible for many players to find a new team to play on before the next season begins, or for scheduling to take place if the SFU team is reinstated. The uncertainty has been destabilizing and demoralizing, according to the filed affidavits and public comments by players. "The hardest thing about this process is looking around at the faces, at all my guys who it could be their last season playing together as a team, and to see that stripped away from them is just devastating," said Key'Shaun Dorsey, a second-year player from Surrey, B.C. — southeast of Vancouver — who is not part of the lawsuit.As a local, Dorsey hasn't had to deal with the same housing, academic and visa issues other players say the upheaval has caused them.But he says he can't stay at SFU to study if the team is not reinstated."My dream is to play football," said Dorsey. "It would mean the world to have one more season."
title: 5 SFU football players sue university over axed varsity program
